did.abstract: Chairman of the Center for Automotive Research (CAR) and previously Director of the University of Michigan’s Office of Automotive Transportation (OSAT). Collection documents Cole’s activities as the Director of OSAT and his consulting work.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: This collection came from David Cole (donor no. 9088) in January 2010.

accruals.p: Periodic additions to the papers are expected.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open to research.

userestrict.p: David E. Cole has transferred his copyright to the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, David E. Cole papers, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: David E. Cole was a student at the University of Michigan, receiving a B.S.M.E. and Mathematics in 1960, a M.S.M.E. in 1961and Ph.D. in Mechanical Engineering in 1966. He became an Instructor of Mechanical Engineering in 1965, an Assistant Professor from 1966-1971 and an Associate Professor of Mechanical Engineering and Applied Mechanics in 1971. In 1978, Cole became the Director for the Office of Automotive Transportation (OSAT). He was appointed a research scientist at the University of Michigan Transportation Research Institute (UMTRI) in1991. While at the University of Michigan, Cole organized the annual Traverse City Management Briefing Seminar and was involved in the Joint U.S.-Japan Automotive Study. Cole retired from active faculty status in 2000. Soon after his retirement, Cole became a Management Partner of the Environmental Research Institute of Michigan (ERIM), which changed its name to Altarum in 2001. Cole took the position of the Chairman of the Center for Automotive Research (CAR), which was associated with Altarum. In 2003, CAR left Altarum to become a stand-alone non-profit.

An active member of the Society of Automotive Engineers (SAE), Cole was made an SAE fellow in 1986. He was a member of the SAE Board of Directors from 1980-1983 and 1985-1988. Cole served on various boards and committees within the SAE, including the Engineering Activity Board. In addition, Cole was the Technical Program Chairman for the 1988 FISTIA Conference. Cole was active in other professional organizations, and became fellow of the Engineering Society of Detroit (ESD) in 1990. In 2000, Cole received their highest award, the Horace H. Rackham medal. He was a member of the Air Pollution Control Association and the Society of Automotive Analysts. In addition, Cole was on the Board of Directors for the French-American Business Association and was the Chairman for the Automotive Hall of Fame.

Cole did consulting work for numerous companies and government agencies. According to a 1992 email recommending Cole for the medal of the French Order of Merit, he was a consultant in the areas of "vehicle design, internal combustion engines (emphasis on exhaust emissions and fuel efficiency) and strategic automotive industry issues." His many professional roles included the position of Chairman of Environmental Dynamics Inc. and also of the Automotive Consulting Group. Cole was President of Applied Theory Inc., a member of Johnson Controls Technical Advisory Group and of the Allied Corporation Automotive Technology Council, and a board member of Aero Detroit /Auto Dynamics. He was the Director of the Original Equipment Suppliers Association. Cole was also involved in the establishment of five Ann Arbor-based companies.

In his work for the United States Government, Cole served on the U.S.-Canada Free Trade Pact Select Panel, the Energy Engineering Board of the National Research Council and the NASA Space Systems and Technical Advisory Committee. He was a member of the Michigan Economic Development Corporation (MEDC) and was "appointed by Michigan's Governor to the Michigan Technology Tri-Corridor Steering Committee" (Biographical Profile from the University of Michigan). He also served on the Michigan Technology Council, the Economic Development Education Committee and the Michigan Environmental Review Board.

According to the SAE 1981 Ballot for Election of Officers, Cole's research interests included "mixture-motion effects on spark-ignited engine combustion, the development of thermal reactors for emission control, the development and testing of rotary and reciprocating spark-ignition engines, the photographic studies of flames, the optical measurements of both dynamic and thermal phenomena, the influence of vehicle maintenance and engine modifications on exhaust emissions and fuel consumption, automotive coolant evaluation and studies of stratified-charge engines." He also did research on the Wankel engine and studied manufacturer-supplier relationships. Later in his career, Cole focused on "strategic issues related to the restructuring of the North American industry and trends in globalization, technology, market factors, and human resource requirements," according to his biographical profile from the University of Michigan.

Over his professional career, Cole received numerous awards. In addition to the Horace H. Rackham medal, Cole was awarded the National Automobile Dealers Association Foundation's International Freedom of Mobility Award. He received Sweden's Order of the Polar Star in 1994 and was selected by Design News as an engineering leader. In 1998, Cole was named Marketing Educator of the Year by the Society of Marketing Executives and received the Rene Dubos Environmental Award. He received the National Order of Merit from France in 1999.

scopecontent.p: The papers of David E. Cole document his activities as the Director of the Office for the Study of Transportation (OSAT) and his consulting work. This collection contains nine series: University of Michigan; Associations and Government; Company Files; Correspondence; Research; Speaking Engagements; Publications, Papers and Clippings; Topical Files; and Audio-Visual Material.

scopecontent.p: Cole received a Ph.D. in Mechanical Engineering from the University of Michigan, becoming an Assistant Professor in 1966, an Associate Professor in 1971, and Director of OSAT in 1978. This series documents Cole's professional activities at the University of Michigan, including his position as Professor of Mechanical Engineering and the Director of OSAT. The series contains information on the Traverse City Management Briefing Seminar, which was founded by Cole, and various projects related to the University of Michigan.

The Mechanical Engineering Department subseries contains notes, exams and teaching materials for courses that Cole attended and taught. Videos from mechanical engineering classes can be found in the Audio-Visual Material series.

Teaching notes and student tests/experiments (includes photos), 1960s-1970s
Course notes and sample instructional handouts 1970s

Office for the Study of Automotive Transportation (OSAT)

scopecontent.p: Cole became the Director of the Office for the Study of Automotive Transportation (OSAT) in 1978. OSAT was originally called the Center for the Study of Automotive Transportation (CSAT) and was transferred to the University of Michigan Transportation Research Institute (UMTRI) in 1982. This subseries includes material on organizational planning (such as finances and strategic plans), meetings of the executive committee and information on the Automotive Quality Seminars, which were interdisciplinary luncheon seminars on automotive research.

did.unittitle: Center for the Study of Automotive Transportation (CSAT) description
"Review of Operations Through August 1980 and Financial Plans"
"OSAT Review of Current Status and Future Financial and Program Projections," 1982

scopecontent.p: The Traverse City Management Briefing Seminar was a series of engineering and automotive conferences held annually in Traverse City. The seminar focused on future automotive trends and was sponsored by the Office for the Study of Automotive Transportation (OSAT). Cole founded the seminar, the origin of which was a one-day conference on the Wankel engine in 1972, and was heavily involved in the organization of the event. He was responsible for planning and chairing the seminars starting in 1975.

did.unittitle: 1989-1990 notes (includes list of seminar themes from 1975-1989)
Speech summaries in UMTRI (University of Michigan Transportation Research Institute) Research Review 1981-1994 (scattered)

scopecontent.p: The Projects files relate to the various activities in which Cole was involved. These include the Clean Air Car Race, the Urban Vehicle Design Competition and the U.S-Japan Automotive Project.

The Clean Air Car Race was a race from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) to the California Institute of Technology, with the goal to increase public awareness of efforts to create low pollution vehicles. Winners of the contest were determined by a combination of performance, safety, low emissions and time. University of Michigan students entered two cars, a 1970 Volkswagen and a 1970 Chevelle, to compete in the internal combustion category. Cole's involvement in the project included overseeing student activities.

did.unittitle: Including UM students working on an entry
Including Fowler receiving a plaque with Professor Bolt looking on, and a picture of David Olds with VW entry

scopecontent.p: The Urban Vehicle Design Competition (UVDC) was a student-organized contest to design and build a vehicle suitable for use in urban environments. The contest was open to students from U.S. and Canadian universities, and involved roughly 2500 students from 84 universities. Vehicle design goals included creating a car that would handle traffic well in urban areas, but that would also improve exhaust emissions, passenger safety, parkability, energy efficiency and low speed impact protection. The competition was an outgrowth of the 1970 Clean Air Car Race, and was sponsored by SCORE (Student Competition on Relevant Engineering). The University of Michigan contributed two entries designed by students in the ME 498 course taught by Professor Cole, the Urban Car 1000 and 1100. The Urban Car 1000 was a rear-engine, rear-drive car, while the Urban Car 1100 was front-engine, front-drive. This subseries includes vehicle drawings and blueprints.

did.unittitle: Summary of urban vehicle design project
Summary of U of M project, including 1000 and 1100 design descriptions
Photographs and photographic slide of students and urban car
Report on symposium "The Urban Vehicle in 1980" 1972

LP gas offer and engine conversion 1971
Report on Menasco compressible-solid shock isolators 1970

scopecontent.p: The U.S.-Japan Automotive Project subseries contains information on the Joint U.S.-Japan Automotive Study and the International Automotive Industry Forum. The Joint U.S.-Japan Automotive Study was formed in 1981 in response to U.S. demand for information on the Japanese automotive industry. The University of Michigan partnered with Technova (who was the primary supporter and sponsor of the study) to do research on technologies, practices, policies and relationship between manufacturers and suppliers of the automotive industry in both countries. The Center for Japanese Studies at the University of Michigan served as the U.S. Secretariat, while Technova filled this same position for Japan. This study resulted in a comprehensive report written in 1984. During this period, the University of Michigan held several US-Japan Automotive Industry Conferences (later called the International Automotive Industry Conference), where David Cole served on the Planning Committee. The Joint U.S.-Japan Automotive Study led to the formation of the International Automotive Industry Forum, which was established to promote "a continuing dialogue among major institutional participants in the Japanese and U.S. auto industry" and to "identify and clarify the major emergent issues confronting and leading to a restructuring of the world auto industry" (Statement on the International Auto Industry Forum, 1985). Another reason for the creation of the forum was to monitor the development of the industry in relation to the U.S.-Japan Automotive Study's final report. This subseries includes reports, information on meetings, and materials from the International Automotive Industry Forums.

scopecontent.p: The Associations and Government series documents Cole's activities in professional associations and government organizations. Included are materials from the Society of Automotive Engineers (SAE), government projects, information on hearing and testimonies, patents and individual organizations and associations.

Cole was an active member of the Society of Automotive Engineers (SAE). He was elected a Fellow member in 1986, and served on the Board of Directors from 1980 to 1983 and 1985 to 1988. This subseries documents his activities in SAE, including his role on various boards, committees and conferences. In 1983, Cole became the Chairman of the Engineering Activity Board (EAB), which oversaw various activity boards and reviewed technical papers, among other activities. Cole was the Chairman of the Powerplant Activity before becoming Chairman of the EAB, and he was also the Advanced Powerplants Committee Chairman. This subseries contains correspondence and meeting minutes from several boards and committees, including the EAB, the Membership Services Board and the Objectives and Strategic Planning Committee. For a complete list of Cole's positions within the SAE, please see his biography filed in the Company Files series under the French Trade Commission. Cole was the Chairman of the 1988 FISITA Technical Program Committee. Documentation on this conference includes correspondence, meeting minutes and information on session areas and papers. Information on later FISITA conferences can be found in the Topical Files series.

scopecontent.p: This subseries documents three government projects: the Cooperative Automotive Research Program (CARP), the U.S.-Canada Automotive Select Panel and the Auto-in-Michigan (AIM) Project. CARP was a program supported by the government and automotive industry that sponsored automotive projects in 12 major research areas. Cole was the Chairman of the Engine/Fuel and Thermal/Fluid Sciences Advisory Panel. This subseries contains meeting materials and correspondence from that project. Cole was a member of the U.S.-Canada Automotive Select Panel and was involved in the Competitiveness Subcommittee. Materials on this panel include correspondence, meeting minutes and preliminary proposal from OSAT. The Auto-in-Michigan (AIM) Project was created to "target the changing automotive sector with focused economic development programs" (AIM Interim Report). Cole served on the Central Research Team. Included in this subseries are reports from this project.

scopecontent.p: The Organizations subseries documents Cole's activities with various government and professional entities, including his consulting work. This subseries includes materials from Cole's activities as a member of the NASA Space Systems and Technical Advisory Committee, and the Energy Engineering Board of the National Research Council.

did.unittitle: "The Educational Role of the Environmental Research Institute of Michigan" 1979

Western New York Economic Development Corporation 1994

scopecontent.p: The Company Files document Cole's business activities with United States and international corporations, including consulting work, research, arranging corporate sponsors for OSAT and discussion of the Traverse City Management Briefing Seminar. For more documentation on Cole's consulting work, please see the Consulting subseries found in the Research series.

The United States subseries consists of companies that were headquartered in the United States, although many of these corporations also had offices in other countries. Cole served as a member of several boards and committees for US companies, often in the role of a consultant. At Johnson Controls, Cole was a member of two Technical Advisory Boards, the Automotive Systems Group (where he served as chairman) and the Battery Group. He was also a member of Johnson Control's Technical Advisory Group, which was made up of Technical Advisory Board chairpersons. Cole served on the Board of Directors for Mechanical Dynamics as an Audit Committee member and did consulting work for United Technologies Automotive (UTA) as a member of their Technical Advisory Committee. He was on the project team for Ernst & Young's Car Company of the Future project, and also served on the Editorial Advisory Board of Automotive Leadership. This subseries contains material on General Motors, including Cole's correspondence about conferences, presentations and automotive industry issues. Materials on Ford include Cole's correspondence and information on simultaneous development.

scopecontent.p: The International subseries is arranged alphabetically by country or by company. This subseries documents Cole's international business relations, including his business activities with companies from Japan and France. Cole was on the Board of Directors for the French-American Business Association. The French Trade Commission materials contain an email sent to Cole that contains biographical information on his involvement in government organizations, the SAE, his education and employment history, research and a list of his publications.

did.unittitle: Fiat USA, Inc. (Associazione Tecnica dell'Autombile seminar and Italy) 1988, 1992
Cole's biography and list of publications 1992
Fachhochschule Hamburg University of Applied Sciences 1999 undated
World Business Council for Sustainable Development (WBCSD)

scopecontent.p: The Correspondence series contains correspondence written and received by Cole during his affiliation with the University of Michigan. The series is arranged into two subseries by chronological and alphabetical order. The chronological subseries dates from 1979 to 2000 and contains correspondence from Cole's time as the Director of the Office for the Study of Automotive Transportation (OSAT). This correspondence covers a variety of subjects concerning OSAT, such as automotive projects, seminars (including the Traverse City Management Briefing Seminar), staffing/employment, funding and automotive issues and research. The alphabetical subseries is arranged by last name or company and is divided into two groups by date, which is how the subseries was originally arranged. It seems that this subseries focuses more on Cole's professional activities outside of OSAT. Correspondence can be found throughout the collection within other series.

The Research series documents Cole's consulting work and research activities. The Consulting subseries contains information on Cole's consulting work for various companies. Cole provided consulting services for Bendix as part of their Technical Advisory Board. He was a member of the Chevrolet-Pontiac-Canada Group (CPC) Supplier Council Joint Committee and also their College of Engineering Board. This subseries is separate from the Company Files because this division reflects the original arrangement of the collection. The Conference and Seminars subseries documents events that Cole attended or helped to plan. For more documentation on conferences, please see the Speaking Engagements series. Cole's research interests included the Wankel engine, which was an internal combustion engine with a rotary design invented by German engineer Felix Wankel. The Wankel Engine subseries contains correspondence, reports, publications and clippings, and information on the 1972 Wankel Engine Seminar in Traverse City.

scopecontent.p: The Speaking Engagements series documents Cole's activities as a keynote speaker, public lecturer and panel member at various conferences and seminars. Materials include Cole's presentations and speeches, although the majority of the series is composed of correspondence and conference materials. Cole was a speaker at a variety of conferences, as well as at other venues. The series is arranged chronologically, and contains material from 1972 to 2000.

did.unittitle: Engineering Society of Detroit (ESD) Computer Graphics

scopecontent.p: The Publications, Papers and Clippings series contains material authored by Cole, articles about Cole, and publications documenting the automotive industry. The Publications and Papers subseries contains research papers, reports and magazines focused on the automotive industry, as well as Cole's dissertation from 1966. Publications on the Wankel engine can be found in the Research series. The Clippings subseries contains newspaper articles that feature Cole or that were written by him, in addition to articles centered on the automotive industry. In the clippings by subject, the folder headings in quotations represent original headings.

did.unittitle: 1990 Family Car article for Galileo Magazine 1980
Fuel economy book, written in conjunction with Hilliard 1980-1981

scopecontent.p: The Topical Files series contains Cole's subject files. Topics include energy, quality and the electric vehicle. For the "Measuring Cost and Value" paper and management highlights of the Product Development Study, please see Sigma Associates in the Company Files series.

did.unittitle: Automotive Body -- Training and Technology Center 1990s
Partnership for a New Generation of Vehicles Marketplace Acceptance (PNGV) Study 1990s
"Product Development Systems" by the Industrial Development Division 1990

scopecontent.p: The Audio-Visual Material series contains Beta tapes, VHS tapes and one audiocassette. The majority of the series consists of tapes from Cole's Mechanical Engineering courses.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: The Bentley Historical Library also holds some records of the University of Michigan Office for the Study of Automotive Transportation (OSAT).
